To me it seems like having no templates by default makes it seem as if Nautilus is missing critical features, with or without any indication of this.

Yes, it's easy to add the templates a user wants, but there should be basics there in the first place, as I found out when a particularly irritating user told me today "Unreasonably convoluted user interface" just because the template was missing.

That said, from doing some poking around it *sounds* like adding initial templates should be more of a xdg-user-dirs thing (as it's supposed to be creating the directories in the first place, apparently?), but this doesn't appear to occur.

events.target_title: Primay search does not accept whitespace or backspace anymore

note.body:
Hi Milan
it appears that I misinterpreted what I was seeing. I wonder if the below indicates that I have some improperly binded keys?

If I enter a search term and press ENTER, then I get the search results that I expect - the email listing page only shows those emails that match the search string.

If I type a search string and press the backspace key, the search text entry field turns blue and the cursor moves one email up in the email list and no search is performed.

If I type a search string and press the space key, the search text entry field turns blue 
1) if the currently selected email shows the mail body in its entirety in the preview pane, then the cursor jumps to the next unread email.  If the currently selected emails body extends beyond the preview pane, then the body of the email is paged down. Subsequent space bar presses continue to page down until the entire body has been previewed, and the next space bar press jumps the cursor to the next unread email

events.target_title: Primay search does not accept whitespace or backspace anymore

note.body: OK - per  https://projects-old.gnome.org/evolution/keys.shtml  it seems like Scroll Up and Scroll Down are being invoked when I select backspace/space while entering a search term into the search text entry field

events.target_title: Primay search does not accept whitespace or backspace anymore

note.body:
OK - so i just confirmed that if i select an email in the email list and, without entering anything in the search text entry field, I
1) press the backspace key, the cursor jumps backward in the list to the first unread email
2) press the space key, if the entire body is displayed in the preview pane, the cursor jumps to the next unread email. If the body extends beyond the preview pane the cursor is paged down into the body, subsequent spaces page the cursor further down the body until the entire email has been previewed and then the cursor jumps to the next unread email

so it appears that those two key entries are being acted upon as shortcuts for the list/preview panes rather than actual backspace/space in the search text entry field when entering text into the search text entry field.

New search behavior using type-ahead search by default

note.body:
Another attempt to explain why some people expect type-ahead instead of search... The main point to understand that type-ahead is not a search feature, it's a navigation feature. It's a feature for moving in a list. The mental model is analogous to pressing up, down, page up, page down, home or end.

The issue with search is that you lose context. For example, let's say I have files a to z in a directory. I *think* I want file p, so I pre-emptively type p. However, based on a cue, such as file type, file size or modified date, I realize I actually need file q, which was not in the search space for p. With type-ahead (which, again, is a navigation feature) I'm now able to both inspect other files, and move around in the context around file p. With search, the context that includes o and q is lost.

For a more specific use case, imagine the following: You have a directory with files of some kind, let's say image files. You want to find file X, which you don't remember the name of from the top of your head. However, you remember that you worked on Y the same day. You sort the directory by modified date. The directory contains so many files that some are out of view. You type Y, not because yo want to find Y, but because you want to move to Y in the current view and manually explore the context around it. Type to search as it stands today is utterly and completely useless for this use case!

events.target_title: Implement "Jump to file" feature (type ahead)

note.body:
I'll repeat what I said the last time the issue was up. Jump by type-ahead is not a search feature, it's a navigation feature. It's a feature for moving in a list. The mental model is analogous to pressing up, down, page up, page down, home or end.

A common use pattern for me is that I sort files by date and want to know what's *next to* the file I'm searching for in the list. For example, I forgot what I named a project folder, but I know I created it right after another folder that I remember the name of. Type xyz, move down one step. I've downloaded two files, where one has as filename that's a hash or id of some kind (difficult to remember) but I remember I downloaded it the same day as xyz. Again, typ xyz to move to that file and look around. Making type-ahead search is completely and utterly useless for that kind of use case.

I'm making a comment instead of (or in addition to) +1'ing the issue because what I'm describing is a specific use case that's not made "slightly inconvenient" or "disorienting" but is plain impossible with the current behavior.

GDM3 completely ignore pam_group

note.body:
I've run into this issue as well, and I'm seeing the same behavior on Ubuntu 18.04 with gdm3 3.28, if I log in via SSH (no gdm-password PAM rules) my user DOES get assigned the group, but if I log in via GDM then my user does NOT get the group.

I've been doing some testing around this in a Vagrant VM based on 18.04 that is joined to our domain and at first thought I was going crazy, but finding this bug it appears it must be something in gdm or gnome and the chaining of the gdm-environment/gdm-password and including common-auth (since that is typically where pam_group is typically defined.

I was able to verify the fact that this doesn't occur in 16.04 with gdm 3.18 and an otherwise identical LDAP/AD domain joined configured via SSSD. I also enabled the gnome3-staging PPA for 16.04 with `sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:gnome3-team/gnome3-staging && sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade` which allowed me to upgrade to gdm3 3.20 where I still didn't encounter gdm3 breaking pam_group.

I'm also wondering whether `pam_gdm` has anything to do with it but I couldn't really find any references to it in `/etc/pam.d/` or `/usr/share/pam-configs/`.

It appears this type of regression has been discovered and corrected in LightDM, SDDM, and possibly other DMs, often having something to do with initgroups being called and blowing away the groups added by pam_group.

I did find mention of an issue where systemd --user doesn't properly integrate with PAM auth modules, but I'm not certain if that is the case here. https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=851243

events.target_title: Question: How I should convert a GTK module?

note.body:
So even `plotinus`, the blessing command palettes module that let *all menu item positioning disputes quietly die* while at the same time enhancing usability of all gtk+ applications, *will quietly die* because of module support suppression?

https://github.com/p-e-w/plotinus

Do I understand correctly or what does it go with this removal is the chance to globally modify gtk+ behaviour without forking and continuously patching the toolkit unless you get to import your changes upstream?
@ebassi I personally do not understand this argument:

>You get to do what everyone else does: engage with the upstream community, interact with the maintainers and designers, and try to outline your intent. If you get to convince them, good: the toolkit gets a supported feature, and applications get to use it, and test it, properly.

In practice, doesn't this mean additional work for the app developers that want to integrate features like command palettes in their apps without waiting that upstream takes its time to decide whether the feature deserves to be integrated in the toolkit?

Sticking to plotinus, I like a lot what it does and I get to use it *for free* in the applications I've written installing it alongside the app and loading it at runtime, when the user didn't already globally installed by himself:
in that case I got support for it out of the box without writing a single extra line.

So, when (and now if) I will port my app to gtk4 I will have to explicitly replicate a command palette inside my app; so probably it won't get it because, well, there are more important things when you have deadlines.

If I get it right, it seems to me that this external modules suppression will in theory slow down innovation coming from external developers; I wouldn't have lobbied for command palettes if I didn't get to use them in the first place and that *wouldn't have been possible without modules*, apparently.

PS: I'm posting here AND on the mailing list for enhanced reachability.

events.target_title: Question: How I should convert a GTK module?

note.body:
I see.
So your point is that trading the capability to globally modify things in exchange for easier maintenance and faster internal development is acceptable in the gtk context.

I don't work on gtk internals so I can not say if you really need this, I can only trust you would do great things while losing a really cool interface and another way to resist eventually bad and fad-driven UI design changes.

I really hope things won't screw up in the next decade.

events.target_title: Can't disable bit depth auto-detection for indexed files when exporting PNG
Can't disable bit depth auto-detection for indexed files when exporting PNG

note.body:
sorry, not really a bug it turns out, though it would be nice to have more control over png output and maybe tweak indexed palette dialogue...

my issue was a result of how I applied the indexed palette: there was a checkbox already ticked when applying the palette that said 'remove unused colors' or something to that effect.  Gimp still showed this project as 8bpp in app, but would only export the 4bpp version. When I re-did that process and unchecked the remove colors box, the file then saves properly as 8bpp.

suggestion: 'remove unused colors' should be unchecked by default when applying indexed palette.. whenever i've used this function (admittedly, not often), I've specifically wanted the indexed palette -- it seems counter-intuitive that someone would take the time to import an indexed palette but then expect by default that this palette get immediately mangled.  Saving as a compressed 4bpp png instead of 8bpp is a difference of maybe 5kB vs 7kB, rather trivial if thats the reason it's on by default.  Also more png output setting would be nice (ie I *think* my color-removed file would have still worked if it output properly as 8bpp, despite the mostly-empty palette.. could be wrong).  Anyway feel free to close

events.target_title: Program Crashes When a Tool Drags From Canvas to Toolbox Pane with Wacom Tablet

note.body:
A third crash was caused when I softened off of the canvas and into the toolbox section with all the icons on it. While I can't get it to happen on repeat, I have noticed one odd thing in my subsequent attempts: The selected colors reverted back from my Black-White color reset to the colors I had selected before (blue and green). I also noticed that the Convolve Type flips between Sharpen and Blur when I release the tablet pen pressure.

Another interesting thing that I noticed is that, with these two settings, the previous state I had set and the current state that I have set will flip depending on whether I am hovering the softening tool over the canvas or the toolbox pane. In fact, this seems to happen with any tools.

1. Select any tool.
2. Adjust some of the settings in tool properties.
3. Apply the tool to the canvas. While applying, move the tool over the toolbox pane.
4. Release the tool.
5. Settings will revert to the state they were in before you adjusted it.
6. Move the mouse back into the environment.
7. Settings will revert to your adjustments once again.

Perhaps this deserves its own bug support, but this could be connected to the crash.

note.body:
I am seeing this same problem, trying to start Evolution.  I have no idea what happened: my system is running fine, I didn't upgrade any components, I just quit Evolution then started it up again and now Evolution reports:

(evolution:14770): GLib-CRITICAL **: 19:35:04.237: g_strsplit: assertion 'string != NULL' failed

then segmentation faults.  I installed debug symbols and got a stacktrace and the reason for the segfault is quite obvious:

```
(gdb) bt full
#0  0x00007ffff29e5d60 in __GI___strtoul_l (nptr=nptr@entry=0x0, endptr=endptr@entry=0x7fffffffddc8, base=base@entry=10, loc=0x7ffff2d8a960 <_nl_C_locobj>) at ../stdlib/strtol_l.c:547
#1  0x00007ffff6163757 in g_ascii_strtoull (nptr=nptr@entry=0x0, endptr=endptr@entry=0x7fffffffddc8, base=base@entry=10) at ../../../../glib/gstrfuncs.c:1165
#2  0x00007fffe66a68cd in _cogl_gpu_info_parse_version_string (version_string=<optimized out>, tail=tail@entry=0x7fffffffde00, version_ret=version_ret@entry=0x0, n_components=2) at cogl-gpu-info.c:90
        version = 0
        part = <optimized out>
        i = 0
#3  0x00007fffe66a697e in check_mesa_driver_package (strings=<optimized out>, version_ret=0x5555558ff478) at cogl-gpu-info.c:421
        micro_part = <optimized out>
        v = 0x0
#4  0x00007fffe66a6c82 in _cogl_gpu_info_init (ctx=ctx@entry=0x5555558ff400, gpu=gpu@entry=0x5555558ff458) at cogl-gpu-info.c:527
        description = 0x7fffe69281e0 <_cogl_gpu_info_driver_packages>
        strings = {
          renderer_string = 0x0,
          version_string = 0x0,
          vendor_string = 0x0
        }
        i = 0
```
So, in cogl-gpu-info.c where you invoke ctx->glGetString() to retrieve the GL_RENDER, GL_VERSION, and GL_VENDOR strings all of them are returning null.  I have no idea why that might be the case, but the code is in no way prepared for this: it doesn't check for null pointers here and eventually passes a null pointer to g_ascii_strtoull() which dumps core with a SEGV.

Note this Ubuntu Launchpad bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cogl/+bug/1730241

FYI, I have an NVidia GeForce 8400 GS which is older but still works fine for me; I'm using the NVidia proprietary driver version 340.107 which, likewise, is working fine.  I haven't changed anything about this.

glxinfo reports:

```
$ glxinfo
name of display: :1
X Error of failed request: BadValue (integer parameter out of range for operation)
  Major opcode of failed request: 154 (GLX)
  Minor opcode of failed request: 24 (X_GLXCreateNewContext)
  Value in failed request: 0x0
  Serial number of failed request: 93
  Current serial number in output stream: 94
```

At this point I'm not sure if I should reboot or not...

events.target_title: Segmentation fault can occur in cogl_context_new

note.body:
I discovered the problem: my nvidia driver had been updated but I hadn't rebooted, so I found these system messages:
```
Oct 09 09:34:34 homebase kernel: NVRM: API mismatch: the client has the version 340.107, but
                                 NVRM: this kernel module has the version 340.106.  Please
                                 NVRM: make sure that this kernel module and all NVIDIA driver
                                 NVRM: components have the same version.
Oct 09 09:34:34 homebase kernel: NVRM: nvidia_frontend_ioctl: minor 255, module->ioctl failed, error -22
```

I suppose this results in null pointers returned from the various glGetString() calls.  After rebooting things worked fine.

It would be a great thing if cogl could catch this issue and generate some sort of helpful message, rather than dumping core.

Cheers!

events.target_title: Config file contains clear password

note.body:
I don't see any reason why a file is needed here.  Yes, _clearly_ providing secrets on the command line is a non-starter and infinitely worse than writing it to a privileged file.

However as far as I understand it the information is known by NM and NM is invoking the openfortivpn process.  The typical _secure_ way these secrets would be handled is that openfortivpn would have a facility to read the information it needs from stdin, and NM would start it with popen() or the equivalent and pass the configuration via stdin.

This is easy to do, and is extremely secure and ensures no secrets are ever landed on the disk or appear anywhere other than in memory.

One trivial way to do this is allow the `--config` argument to accept the POSIX-standard value `-` to mean stdin, then read the config file from stdin rather than using fopen() to read the file.  Then NM (or whichever process is invoking openfortivpn) simply writes out the same configuration it would have written to a file, but to the pipe to the openfortivpn process's stdin instead.

note.body: I've taken a brief look at the code, and it appears to use `g_socket_listener_add_inet_port` which listens on all interfaces.  I haven't been able to find out how to use the `g_socket_listener` functions to listen on anything but all interfaces.  It appears vino used avahi methods to launch its service.  I guess it would have to be done by essentially reimplementing `g_socket_listener_add_inet_port` but using `g_inet_address_new_loopback` instead of `g_inet_address_new_any`?  Sadly, python is my primary language, so I don't know that I'll be of that much help, but I'm more than happy to test any patches that might emerge from this, just lemme know...  5:)

It happened only when using an old paper-gtk application theme (switching to adwaita no shrinking occurred).

events.target_title: WIP: Initial attempt at adding loopback support
Support `None` authentication method

note.body:
Here's a patch (I didn't want to put it on top of the existing merge request, but happy to do so if it'll help).

It adds None as a potential authentication mechanism.  It currently does no checks to ensure that this isn't enabled on an unfirewalled machine connected to the internet, meaning it could easily be classed as a security hole (although it requires conscious effort by the user to enable).

Once the loopback option is added, it should be possible to reject or fall back to prompt if loopback isn't set, but I don't know how best to describe that within the settings schema.

[gnome-remote-desktop-none-auth.patch](/uploads/41237bf0bf9d3e43df70d096321745ba/gnome-remote-desktop-none-auth.patch)

events.target_title: Add support for Swatchbooker's SBZ colour palette format
Add the free CIE palettes from freieFarbe/free Colour to GIMP
Add support for Swatchbooker's SBZ colour palette format

note.body: This isn't realistic. GIMP should continue support for its legacy format -- no need to replace it. If you look at the real world, however, everyone has moved to LAB, so that's what required. HLC/LCh is just another way to define LAB, but RIPs etc. can only handle LAB, not HLC. Pantone went even further and published a standard (CxF) that can also use spectral colours. Outside some ink mixing software for print, only Scribus supports this format. So, as far as I'm concerned, LAB support (and of course SBZ, as well as some Adobe, especially ACO and ASE, all documented on the Swatchbooker site, or Corel formats, wich also use LAB) is sufficient.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body:
This bug prevents VirtualGL from working properly with GDM 3.  Oddly, though, the RHEL/CentOS 7 implementation (GDM 3.26.2.1) works fine, whereas this failure occurs on all versions of Fedora since at least release 22 (GDM 3.16.1.1) and on Ubuntu 16 and later (refer to https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=851769 and https://github.com/VirtualGL/virtualgl/issues/65).  It is particularly problematic on Ubuntu 18.04, which now ships with GDM 3 rather than LightDM as the default DM.

Note that the aforementioned Red Hat bug report initially described what might have been a separate issue with the SELinux policy.  That issue was apparently resolved, but GDM 3 still refuses to read /etc/gdm/Init/Default.  The current issue cannot be SELinux-related, since Ubuntu does not use SELinux.

Currently I am telling my users to avoid GDM 3 altogether and use LightDM instead.

Maybe most users don't need this to work properly, but anyone who wants to run 3D applications remotely does need it to work properly, and I would appreciate your prompt attention to the matter.  Until this is fixed, the GDM man page is a work of fiction.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body:
Current data points:

- RHEL 7.5 w/ GDM 3.26.2.1 works, but F27 w/ GDM 3.26.2.1 doesn't.  I investigated the RHEL 7.5 GDM SRPM but couldn't find any obvious patches that fixed this problem.  That would suggest that the problem resides outside of the GDM package (although it might be in a GNOME library called by GDM.)

- The bug is also in Fedora 28 (GDM 3.28.2).

- The bug is also in Ubuntu 18.04 (GDM 3.28.2), which means that the bug cannot be SELinux-related.  This also strongly suggests that it's a GNOME bug rather than a distro bug.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body: @halfline what's your point?

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body:
If there is, I am certainly unaware of it.  VirtualGL has to get access to the X server while it's sitting at the login prompt, in order to create Pbuffers in GPU memory and to create fully-accelerated OpenGL contexts.  VGL has been doing things that way since 2004.  And yes, I know about EGL, and we're researching how to use that, instead of a GPU-attached X server, to do hardware-accelerated off-screen OpenGL rendering.  However, currently EGL doesn't provide the same features that GLX does, so at the moment, being able to establish a GLX context on the GPU-attached X server is critical to the functionality of our product.  Maybe there's a way to skin this cat using XWayland or something (?)

LightDM works fine, so apparently it's still running the X server as root.  That is the easiest workaround for now, but I really would like to find a better solution.  In the meantime, be aware that the GDM man page clearly says that /etc/gdm/Init/Default will be executed.  Given that it isn't, that man page is incorrect.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body:
VirtualGL is fundamentally a way for multiple users to share the same GPU.  It uses LD_PRELOAD to intercept and rewrite GLX commands from 3D applications, so that it can redirect OpenGL rendering into off-screen Pbuffers, read back the rendered pixels in real time, and draw them into the appropriate place in the application's X windows.  In this way, VGL enables OpenGL acceleration in virtual X servers/X proxies, such as Xvnc, that normally would not have access to OpenGL acceleration because their framebuffers are resident in system memory rather than video memory.  With such an X proxy solution (we provide our own called TurboVNC that is optimized for the types of images that 3D applications generate), both the Linux desktop and 3D acceleration can be virtualized.  This allows many different users to run OpenGL applications on the same machine simultaneously, with hardware acceleration, and isolated from each other.  VirtualGL always runs in user space, but all instances of it (regardless of whose account they are running under) access the same GPU-attached X server.

I guess I don't fully understand what you mean about GDM starting the X server as part of the user session.  Doesn't it have to start an X server in order to display the login prompt?  It is that login prompt X server that VirtualGL normally uses to access the GPU.

I am not sure what an autostart file is, but if it runs in a particular user's session, then it wouldn't be appropriate.  The whole idea is that, on a VirtualGL server, the "root" X server (which we call the "3D X server") is never used for anything but VirtualGL.  It sits at the login prompt forever, and often the machine is headless, so you couldn't actually log in locally even if you wanted to.  There are security ramifications to this, of which we're fully aware, but again, we don't have a lot of choices.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body: Also, to clarify, I wouldn't expect Init/Default to be invoked unless GDM was configured with WaylandEnable=false.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body:
For our purposes, the separate X server isn't an issue, because VirtualGL servers generally sit at the login prompt forever.  So all we really care about is the X server that is being used to display the login screen.  The reason why we chose the approach we did is that, back in the day, headless GPUs weren't a thing, and we wanted to be able to install our software on "factory" Linux configurations without making any deep modifications to them.  Some people still desire that kind of configuration, because they may be using VGL to access their own personal workstation remotely rather than as a way to deploy 3D applications on demand to multiple users.  I'm not sure exactly what a "GLX lock" is.  Never seen that in the Xorg code.

It does sound as if our current approach of using LightDM instead of GDM is the least painful approach for now.  Again, though, I would very much welcome any ideas regarding how to do what we need to do without relying on any display manager.  Also, I think that the GDM man page needs to be updated to reflect the fact that the Default scripts are now useless.

events.target_title: gdm does not run /etc/gdm/*/Default scripts properly!

note.body: I ultimately worked around this by using a greeter autostart script.  Sorry I didn't understand what that was when you suggested it above, but when combined with `WaylandEnable=false`, that gives us what we need.  You can close this issue.

events.target_title: Meld Windows shows error on startup "There was a problem starting c:\Program"
Directory with pre-1970 timestamps fails on Windows
Directory with pre-1970 timestamps fails on Windows

note.body:
I spent a bit of time trying to debug this, although I'm a bit out of my depth. I managed to get Meld running in mingw-w64 using MSYS2. Only the 3.19.1 tag would run; both 3.18.3 and the current HEAD gave GTK errors, although that's almost certainly due to my setup rather than a problem in Meld.

* Running in 32-bit mode, the diff now completes successfully, but the date of that file shows as 25 Feb 1987 instead of 1851 (obviously there's a 32-bit overflow somewhere). I notice the usual Windows build is 32 bit so this is a change in behaviour from that. I'm not sure if this is due to changes in 3.19 vs 3.18 or whether it's due to a difference in my environment (MSYS2) vs the one that the public installer was built in.

* Running in 64-bit mode, the diff also completes succesfully (expandos appear next to all the directories and I get a message saying that they are identical). But attempting to expand the `BEACH` directory throws an uncaught Python exception `OSError` in this line in `cellrenderers.py`, with `value` equal to `-3753712064.0`:

      mod_datetime = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(value)

* It turns out that on Windows `datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp()` throws an `OSError` if called with a negative argument (perhaps Windows doesn't hold time zone information that far back?). For small negative values like `-1.0` the UTC version of the function `datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp()` does not throw an error, but for large negative values like the `-3753712064.0` even that function does! (It is fine with large positive arguments like `3753712064.0`.) But you can work around this by adding a `timedelta` to the Epoch... 

* Running in 64-bit mode, I tried the `timedelta` hack and I found it fixes the problem: the diff (still) completes succesfully and the date of the file shows up correctly. Here is the code I used to replace the above line (and the next one):

      try:
          mod_datetime = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(value)
          time_str = mod_datetime.strftime(self.DATETIME_FORMAT)
      except OSError:
          mod_datetime_utc = datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(0) + datetime.timedelta(seconds=value)
          time_str = mod_datetime_utc.strftime(self.DATETIME_FORMAT) + " (UTC)"

* Feel free to use this snippet or something like it. I added the text ` (UTC)` to make clear that this is not in the user's local timezone, which I think is important to note, but I'm not sure how you'd localise that. As a related aside, an option to show UTC rather than local times seems like it would be useful anywa.

events.target_title: LoadImage (Win32 API) fails on GIMP produced BMP file

note.body:
@schumaml Transparency is well defined for indexed images. I think that the headers are not correct. 

Non-indexed BMP doesn't really support transparency. It just acts a wrapper for different compression algorithms that appeared much later. No one should be using BMP for transparent images. It is for loading system resources, like icons. 

It's a defunct format, except for the fact that it works with native Windows APIs and is the internal storage medium for all software based rendering, i.e. what traditional Win32 applications use.

This is why it needs to work with Windows' APIs. That is the only domain in which it is used, outside of people who goof around with MS Paint :)

This is a problem that can be assessed in minutes, and solved in an afternoon. Unfortunately, I don't have either for GIMP. I apologize. But that's not why I reported the matter. Were I GIMP's maintainer I'd be very grateful to learn of it. Please don't discount Windows' users.

events.target_title: LoadImage (Win32 API) fails on GIMP produced BMP file

note.body:
@cbrt64 Glad somebody's noticed this! I will update GIMP next time. BMP is foremost an asset for Windows software workers. It needs to be technically correct, more than it needs to be a picture storage option. There's literally no other reason to support BMP outside of preparing images for Win32 APIs, of which there are no shortage :)

EDITED: BTW, I wanted to say it's a wonder how these things go unnoticed/unaddressed for years on end, but that I see it all the time. Still never ceases to amaze me :)

events.target_title: System freezes when using v 1.4

note.body:
I have the same problem. By each line while translating, used total system memory keeps climbing steadily until 100% of RAM is in use (I myself don't have swap enabled). Program itself doesn't claim all the RAM, instead all of that memory is under "caching" (see attached file which shows the system monitor and top command while using the software after some minutes). Shutting down gnome-subtitles frees the memory.

I have version 1.4-1 of the software, on Arch linux. Kernel is 4.17.14-arch1-1-ARCH. After this software has taken all the available RAM to buff/cache, then everything slows down, until after a few seconds the OS locks completely because it runs out of RAM and I have to do a hard reboot. This happens every single time while using the program, essentially making this unusable at the moment.

And this happens without any video, i.e. it is not video-related. Just doing simple subtitle translation from one file to another (both are .srt files).
Memory creeping pauses when I pause translating, but continues immediately where it left after I continue using the software.![Screenshot](/uploads/adffa4d283ca48cc939b3c054e5604c3/Screenshot.png)

It'd be good if the default was changed, given that it's a standard on multiple platforms. It's really frustrating when you try to redo in Gimp and instead it just undos some more.

events.target_title: Add sync option for NextCloud
Rename this project

note.body:
@nE0sIghT 

When I first learned about the extension, I was linked to [this wiki page](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GnomeShellIntegrationForChrome/Installation) for installation. Based on the title, I figured this page was Chrome-specific, so I scoured the wiki for pages for other browsers. Unsuccessful, I thought that there was just no extension for other browsers. I didn't want to install Chrome, so I was ready to give up. Fortunately, though, I thought to look at the installation page one last time and found a link for Firefox.

If the extension was titled less confusingly, it would save me a lot of frustration and time. I hope that's a strong enough argument for renaming the project.

And if it isn't, please at least change:
- The title of the [wiki page](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GnomeShellIntegrationForChrome/Installation) to "Gnome Shell Integration for Browsers: Installation Guide"
- The description of this Gitlab project to "GNOME Shell integration for Chrome, Firefox, and Opera".

events.target_title: Add sync option for NextCloud

note.body: @aklapper Alright, I changed the task to concern NextCloud in particular. OneDrive and other services can be covered in another issue, if anyone here is interested in those.

note.body: I'm disappointed with this theme. As a user, where can I revert this? By default colored icons are easier to teach children and adults to start with GIMP.

events.target_title: GIMP 3.00/2.99 Dark Theme

note.body:
I'm using the Debian unstable version:

ii  gimp                                   2.10.2-1                                           amd64        GNU Image Manipulation Program
ii  gimp-data                              2.10.2-1                                           all          Data files for GIMP

My opinion is as part of the instructions that teach kids, teens and adults to use GIMP. There is also more visual agility to identify icons in color distinction. Please, it will be more complicated to keep this theme dark by default. Keep the 'icons legacy/colour' and the professional wants to work with dark theme, make the change. Gimp is more joyful and colorful happy.

Thank you to the community and devels GIMP. To sensitize, see the profile of who needs to use the colorful Gimp: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LAdsE4ruP9I

(An old video record of the kdenlive and gimp workshop; But I am always available and applying similar courses.)

Switching keyboard layout with modifier keys
Switching keyboard layout with modifier keys

note.body:
>> make keyboard indicator show actual layout

> That's already the case here, running 3.28 on Fedora:

I meant that if we choose additional keys to switch layout using Gnome Tweaks, then the keyboard indicator doesn't react to those keys, because they switch current group index only in xkbcommon library inside gnome-shell. So they switch the layout but the indicator doesn't reflect that.

>> be able to use any other combinations like Ctrl + Shift for switching layouts

> That's already possible in Tweaks under "Keyboard & Mouse > Additional Layout Options".

Sadly, but no. If I choose Left Control to switch layouts via Tweaks then I cannot use it for combinations like `Ctrl + C` because when I press Control it will trigger layout switching and will be consumed. This is a problem that has been forever in X server and was inherited by xkbcommon. In X if you bind actions (like xkb actions, or key grabs) to modifiers then you cannot use them as modifiers anymore. Because they are "consumed" on keydown event.

For comparison, in Windows you can switch layouts using `Ctrl + Shift`. Layout switching occurs on release only if no other keys were pressed. So other combinations like `Ctrl + Shift + F` still work. Many years ago in MSDOS there was a layout switching utility that would switch layout by pressing left or right Shift key. 

Some distributions like Ubuntu [solved this problem by patching XKB extension](https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-control-center/+bug/36812?comments=all) in X server so that it doesn't follow the XKB spec and switches layouts on keyup event.

I also found that Plasma developers made [their own solution for binding actions to modifier-only shortcuts](https://blog.martin-graesslin.com/blog/2016/08/modifier-only-shortcuts-available-in-plasma-5-8/) to allow opening a menu by pressing Windows key. So the problem exists and every DE developer seem to solve it their own way instead of making a standard. 

> That's outside of GNOME.

Then maybe someone knows where it can be solved?

note.body:
No, I can't code in C. But I'll make an offer.

I know a fair bit about metadata. I do a blog and campaign for best, well decent, metadata practices. It's pretty important IMHO that some Open Source photo applications develop standards-compliant metadata functionality. 

It looks like you're pretty close. I would be glad to help any way I can. I can offer guidance with standards and functionality and I can do testing/QA (Which isn't actually trivial, given how monumentally convoluted and generally screwed up the topic is.) I do this pro bono for commercial software so it would be an honor to make the same contribution here.

At a first glance, to looks to me like GIMP is reading IPTC metadata quite well. There are a few fields that are labeled unclearly, and we should talk about your reading order, but it looks like you've got that part of the battle nearly won.

My copy of 2.10.4 isn't writing to any expected places at all. It IS writing to somewhere. I can save an XCF and reopen it and metadata is preserved. But when I look in ExifTool, there's nothing in either the IIM or XMP. (Or in the three semantically equivalent Exif fields, for that matter) Clearly, there's a bug in the house. So, I have no idea how you are doing on the write side.

To bring everybody up to date on the current state of descriptive metadata for photos, ca. mid-2018, here's a super short version:

The schema for the data is the IPTC standard. For practical purposes, there is no other. That standard tells us what the data is and where to put it. "Putting it" is governed by the IPTC's own IIM spec, Adobe's XMP spec, the JEITA's Exif spec, and loosely by the Metadata Working Group's Guidelines. The current specs can be found in one place on a page on my blog, at metadatamatters.blog/what-is-metadata/

There are about twenty basic IPTC fields that appear in duplicate in both the IIM and XMP data blocks. There are a further eight or ten or so fields within the IPTC Core (- v1.2. I hate using the word "core", but really, this is the "core" spec) that appear in only the XMP. And there's a slew of extended fields. Then there are three fields in the Exif, (which do actually exist for a reason beyond busting the chops of those of us who work in the field) that are semantically equivalent to corresponding IPTC fields. The, well, a... challenge is keeping all those bits synchronized so that applications can interoperate, which is the point of the whole thing in the first place. The users, of course, are blissfully unaware of all that. They just put a value in the Copyright field, and they don't care that it's really in three places.

About ten years ago, there was great optimism for the idea that the IPTC-IIM standard was "the old way" and IPTC via XMP would be the "new way". Didn't happen. Today and in the foreseeable future, many/most applications still rely on IIM. And those fields in the Exif continue to confuse things.

It's all fiddly enough that nobody gets it right on the first pass. And that's before even thinking about functionality to benefit the users of a particular program.

If you have somebody who can do the hard stuff, I'll volunteer to guide the rest of the way.  :-)

I don't get by here very often. If Github's notification feature fails to get me, please ping me through the contact form on my website.

note.body:
What I know about Photoshop...

In terms of subset, both Photoshop and GIMP are (today) pretty exhaustive. Both support virtually the entire IPTC Core and Extended schemas. As well as DICOM.

Photoshop writes the synchronized fields to all three data blocks (apart from a couple rather uncommon fields that have bugs). 

That includes writing to the three fields in the Exif, which is an arguable matter. (For what it's worth, IMHO I agree with Adobe there. I think staying in sync is more important that than my sqeemishness about overwriting log data.) 

On the read side, I believe Adobe uses the (unnecessarily complicated in my opinion) Metadata Working Group Guidlines read-order logic. I haven't actually run tests to confirm that, though. 

Standards compliance is a big thing to them, given their position in the industry.

events.target_title: IIM metadata not being written

note.body:
This is interesting. I was just now looking in the Metadata Working Group Guidelines in the context of a different project and came upon this pearl of wisdom, which may provide some historical context:

 >Creator
> SHOULD NOT create IPTC-IIM unless backward compatibility with non-compliant Consumers that >don't read XMP is a requirement – otherwise SHOULD write XMP.


...well, yeah. "backward compatibility with non-compliant Consumers" is pretty much always a requirement. It's now eight years later and many/most applications still can't properly read XMP. 


We shouldn't laugh too hard at the expense of the MWG. They were writing back in 2009~2010. Back then, everybody thought that IIM would be phased out for IPTC via XMP in short order. Now it's looking like that is still a long time coming. I haven't checked old versions of the IPTC spec to see if the language has changed over the years. But now there's no equivocation. The synced fields need to be in both blocks.

events.target_title: Hint how to separate keywords in Metadata > Description

note.body:
@lillolollo @ellestone A comma and a space seems to be the defacto standard. 

Many applications use an interface that requires the user to type keywords one at a time in a field and then commit them to the keywords field where they are separated with commas and spaces. Personally, I think that's annoying. Comma-space is one of the few things I can type without making a typo. A tip as the OP suggests would be fine for me.

As Elle Stone points out, hierarchical keywords are stored every which way by different applications. IMHO it's wrong-headed to store them separately or differently. Doing so makes a mess for other applications and the only thing the user "gains" is the ability to edit keywords hierarchically, en masse, in the given application. Which is dangerous in addition to muddying the water. (Not the mention irrelevant in an application like GIMP that doesn't do asset management.) Commas and spaces are just fine for hierarchical keywords, too.

At some point, after we get all the low-level stuff straightened out, it might be nice to talk about a fancy keywording interface. 

I wrote a ton about keywording in these posts. There are a bunch of ideas for interface features in them, too.  https://www.carlseibert.com/keywording-considerations-start/
https://www.carlseibert.com/keywording-in-photo-mechanic-part-1/
https://www.carlseibert.com/keywording-in-photo-mechanic-part-2/

bus-launch: use __linux__ over __linux
Make GTestDBus work with dbus-broker

note.body:
The easiest way to fix this is to depend on `dbus-tools` on Fedora. But I suspect that GTest is part of the regular builds, so this would pull in `dbus-tools` (which also pulls in dbus-daemon) for all regular systems, which we probably want to avoid.

If you want to support other buses than dbus-daemon, I guess you would need to try both, dbus-daemon and dbus-broker in sequence. We did something like this for at-spi2:

    https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/at-spi2-core/commits/master/bus/at-spi-bus-launcher.c

dbus-broker-launch has a different command-line than dbus-daemon, but should provide the same features. In particular, you must use socket-activation (meaning the caller creates the socket and passes it to dbus-broker via execve).

The question remains what kind of packaging dependencies you want. The `dbus` package on Fedora now only provides a system and user bus, it no longer provides any specific implementation. So if GTest supports both dbus-daemon and dbus-broker, on Fedora you will need an explicit dependency on `/usr/bin/dbus-broker-launch`.

note.body:
I'd like to amend the bug report:

- I've attached an updated glade xml file.  I added the main window id so that it will work with main.py

- it appears that glade doesn't add an id field to connect the GtkImage object declared at the top (which aliases gtk-missing-image) with the place where it is used in the GtkImageMenuItem (where the image id is "__glade_unnamed_22").

- I ran glade 3.18 in a VM on Mint 18 (Ubuntu 16.04), and it worked there (created the GtkImage id correctly, and used correctly in the GtkImageMenuItem).  I suspect something got refactored when the UI was changed?
